posts.name: akoscielski3
posts.cooked:
Hall of Fame Team 1114 Simbotics is excited to release the CAD model of our 2025 robot, Simbot Suzuki.  

Our Season Recap highlights our focus on a competitive robot at our first competition. We ignored the deep climb, ground algae, and floor coral. At Niagara College, we achieved a 7-5 record and ranked 4th. Our alliance selection and playoff run brought us to Match 13, though we lost after an elevator issue.  

We addressed small problems and developed a deep cage climber, designed and built for the McMaster District event. Testing revealed plate issues, but we adapted and succeeded in eliminations until Match 13.  

At Provinces, we improved and climbed many matches. The chain issue affected climbs, leading to a loss in Match 13. Our alliance selection and another playoff run ended similarly.  

World Championship saw similar success, ending in 6th place and forming our own alliance.  

Thank you to our students, mentors, volunteers, parents, and sponsors for this season's success. Questions about our design or decisions are welcome!

posts.name: Dominick Ferone
posts.cooked: Love the robot! Just curious, on the climber, I presume it’s a kraken pinion that’s missing for the pivot? What’s the final gear ratio of the whole climber? Also, how did the energy chain support work? Is it just a channel to help keep the energy chain contained more or less?

posts.name: Max Swanson
posts.cooked: I'm from Team 2052 and thoroughly enjoyed collaborating with you all during Champs this year. Your team and robot delivered an outstanding performance, and I am delighted to have been chosen as your first selection for the playoffs.

posts.name: Rethum C
posts.cooked: Why did the team decide against including ground coral, and what issues were identified during the build phase?

posts.name: Samjackjoetedpaulbill
posts.cooked: Congratulations to the entire 1114 team on their run at Archimedes! We were hopeful to see multiple Canadian teams on Einstein, and it was very close indeed.

posts.name: Vincent Banks
posts.cooked: has anyone ever noticed how tough the simbotics logo is? who made it, ??

posts.name: akoscielski3
posts.cooked:
Correct, it is a Kraken Pinion, 11T, so the gear ratio would have been 11:80 and 18:80 with a final gear ratio of 32.32:1.  

The Lexan piece that you see in the design was never installed because we didn’t feel we needed it. Instead, the energy chain is being supported by the 3 aluminium brackets that the Lexan piece was supposed to mount to. It worked very well, and designing in the energy chain (which we don’t normally do) was very helpful and allowed us to have a great working energy chain that didn’t have flaws throughout the season.  

Thanks for the questions!

posts.name: akoscielski3
posts.cooked: We loved working with you all. We had a great run in the playoffs and our alliance worked very well together. This was a great robot this year, and we wish you the best this offseason and next season. We hope to see you at Champs again next year.

posts.name: akoscielski3
posts.cooked: The main reason we skipped floor coral was because it was lower on our priority list, so we focused on loading station coral instead. Our priority list included Drive Manoeuvrability (Swerve), Intake from Loading Station, L4 Coral, Remove Algae from Reef, and others. Some features were added easily without complicating the robot, such as introducing the algae mechanism before the deep climber. Certain items, like algae and coral from the ground, were ignored due to their complexity.

posts.name: akoscielski3
posts.cooked:
Thank you!

Lucky enough, we saw multiple teams on Einstein 2056 and 4946!

posts.name: Samjackjoetedpaulbill
posts.cooked: We apologize for the abrupt comment. Rather than attempt to edit our post, we'll keep it brief—just a quick note to share that we were hoping to see **even more** Canadian teams on Einstein.
